What Philosophy Is

  • Philosophy is all of rational inquiry except for science
  • Philosophical issues fall into three big topic areas: metaphysics, epistemology, and ethics

Metaphysics

  • Concerned with the nature of reality
  • Includes questions about existence of God, nature of human free will, and more
  • Metaphysics aims at better understanding how claims about reality hang together

Epistemology

  • Concerned with the nature of knowledge and justified belief
  • Deals with questions about what we can know and how we can know it
  • Raises skepticism about certain areas of knowledge

Ethics

  • Concerned with what we ought to do, how we ought to live, and how we ought to organize our communities
  • Philosophy takes seriously the possibility of rational inquiry into moral issues
  • Questions the idea that morality is simply a matter of authority

The Value of Philosophy

  • Philosophy opens the mind to new possibilities and challenges conventional thinking
  • Though it may not provide definitive answers, it liberates us from narrow-mindedness
  • Uncertainty in philosophy allows for exploration and wonder

Reading: "The Value of Philosophy" by Bertrand Russell

  • Russell argues that philosophy reveals the limitations of our beliefs and opens us up to new ideas

Review and Discussion Questions

  • Questions about the nature of philosophy and its value
  • Questions about the ideas presented in Russell's "The Value of Philosophy"
